source.name: Seattle Public Utilities
source.notes: Based on Seattle Public Utilities official guidelines. Seattle has mandatory composting.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Seattle accepts #1-#7 rigid plastics
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid

materials.name: Plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: All rigid plastic #1-#7 accepted in Seattle
commonMistakes: No styrofoam; it's banned in Seattle

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food in them

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle separately)
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Seattle DOES accept glass in curbside recycling (unlike Austin)
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Place in or beside blue recycling bin
notes: Clean cardboard goes in blue bin
commonMistakes: Food-soiled cardboard goes in GREEN compost bin, not blue

materials.name: Paper and newspapers
instructions: Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Clean, dry paper goes in blue bin
commonMistakes: Food-soiled paper goes in GREEN compost bin
Don't bag paper in plastic bags

materials.name: Book
instructions: Donate if in good condition. Seattle Public Library, Goodwill, Half Price Books
If damaged, place in blue recycling bin
notes: Donating is always better than recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Milk / juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Cartons accepted in Seattle curbside
commonMistakes: Don't flatten

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Place in blue recycling bin
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if pressurized

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: Place ALL food waste in green compost bin. Seattle REQUIRES composting
It is ILLEGAL to put food in the garbage in Seattle
All food accepted: meat, dairy, bones, fish, fruit, vegetables, everything
notes: Seattle has MANDATORY composting; you can be fined up to $50 for putting food in garbage
Seattle's industrial composting handles all food types safely
This law has been in effect since 2015
commonMistakes: NEVER put food in the trash; it's against Seattle law
All food goes in green bin; no exceptions

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in green compost bin
Large branches: cut to 4 feet and bundle
notes: Yard waste and food waste share the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
instructions: Place in green compost bin. Seattle composts ALL food-soiled paper
Pizza boxes, paper plates, napkins, paper towels, paper bags with food stains. ALL go green
This is a key Seattle rule: food-soiled paper is compost, not recycling or trash
notes: Seattle is one of the few cities where pizza boxes go in compost, not recycling
This rule prevents contamination of the blue recycling bin
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in blue recycling; it contaminates clean paper
Don't put it in trash; it's required to go in green compost

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT put in blue recycling bin
Take to QFC, Safeway, or Fred Meyer for store drop-off recycling
Otherwise place in garbage
notes: Plastic bags jam Seattle's recycling machinery
Many grocery stores in Seattle accept bags
commonMistakes: Never bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Styrofoam
instructions: Styrofoam is BANNED in Seattle; food service businesses cannot use it
Do not put in blue recycling, green compost, or garbage
Take to a transfer station for proper disposal
Packing styrofoam: take to North or South Transfer Station
notes: Seattle banned styrofoam food service containers in 2009
This includes cups, plates, containers, and trays
Packing peanuts can be returned to UPS stores
commonMistakes: Don't put in any curbside bin
If you received styrofoam in a package, take to transfer station

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to a hazardous waste drop-off event
Or take to North/South Transfer Station
Tape terminals of lithium batteries
notes: Batteries cause fires in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to North or South Transfer Station
Best Buy also accepts e-waste
Delete personal data first
notes: Washington state has an e-waste recycling law
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a hazardous waste collection event
Latex paint: can dry out with kitty litter and garbage
Oil-based: must go to hazardous waste
notes: Seattle has regular hazardous waste collection events
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to any pharmacy with a drug take-back kiosk
Bartell Drugs and many pharmacies in Seattle participate
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds and trash
notes: Washington state has a statewide drug take-back program
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Goodwill or Value Village
Textile recycling bins throughout Seattle
Worn-out textiles accepted in bins
notes: Seattle has many donation options
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Candy wrapper
instructions: Place in garbage
Metallized plastic; not recyclable
notes: Not accepted in any Seattle bin except garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling or compost

materials.name: Chip bag
instructions: Place in garbage
Metallized plastic; not recyclable
notes: The metallic interior cannot be separated
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: In Seattle, lined paper cups go in the GREEN compost bin
Most Seattle coffee shops use compostable cups
Plastic lids: blue recycling bin
notes: Seattle requires food service businesses to use compostable containers
Many cups in Seattle are commercially compostable
commonMistakes: Check if the cup says compostable; most in Seattle are
Non-compostable lined cups go in garbage

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Place in garbage
notes: Not compostable in Seattle's program
commonMistakes: Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Receipt
instructions: Place in garbage; thermal paper contains BPA
notes: Don't put in recycling or compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Cooking oil / grease
instructions: Collect in sealed container
Take to North or South Transfer Station
notes: Never pour down the drain
commonMistakes: Don't pour down sink

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to transfer station or Home Depot
LED: e-waste recycling
Incandescent: wrap and garbage
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL in garbage

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to transfer station or auto parts store
notes: Most auto parts stores accept for free
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to North or South Transfer Station
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous in garbage
commonMistakes: Never puncture

materials.name: Needles / sharps
instructions: Place in sharps container
Take to pharmacy or transfer station
notes: Never put loose in garbage
commonMistakes: Never put in recycling

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Take to North or South Transfer Station
Or schedule a special pickup
notes: Fee applies at transfer station
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Fruit / fruit scraps
instructions: Place in green compost bin. REQUIRED by Seattle law
notes: It is illegal to put food in the garbage in Seattle
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage; you can be fined

materials.name: Vegetables / vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in green compost bin; required by law
notes: All vegetables must go in compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in green compost bin. Seattle accepts all meat and bones
Required by law; do not put in garbage
notes: Seattle's mandatory composting includes all meat and dairy
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage; it's illegal in Seattle

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place in green compost bin; required by Seattle law
notes: All dairy must be composted in Seattle
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage
Rinse and recycle the container separately

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Place in green compost bin
notes: Required by law
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Eggs / eggshells
instructions: Crush and place in green compost bin
notes: Add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

materials.name: Coffee grounds / tea bags
instructions: Coffee grounds and filters: green compost bin
Paper tea bags: green compost bin
notes: Great for composting
commonMistakes: Check tea bags are paper

materials.name: Snacks and candy (food)
instructions: The food: green compost bin (required)
The wrapper: garbage
notes: Separate food from wrapper
commonMistakes: Don't put wrappers in compost

materials.name: Condiments and sauces
instructions: The sauce: green compost bin
The container: rinse and blue recycling bin
notes: Separate container from contents
commonMistakes: Don't recycle containers with sauce in them

materials.name: Beverages / drinks
instructions: Pour leftover liquid down drain
Recycle the container in blue bin
notes: Focus on recycling the container
commonMistakes: Empty containers before recycling

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in garbage
Do NOT compost pet waste
notes: Pet waste is one of the few things that does go in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put in green compost bin

materials.name: Bubble wrap / packing
instructions: Place in garbage
Or take plastic film to store drop-off
notes: Plastic film jams recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue bin

materials.name: Cereal box
instructions: Flatten and place in blue recycling bin
Remove and trash the plastic liner
notes: Clean paperboard goes in blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't forget the plastic liner; that's garbage

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off food residue
Ball up and place in blue recycling bin
notes: Clean foil is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle heavily soiled foil

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Factory reset first
Take to Best Buy or transfer station
notes: Illegal to trash e-waste in Washington
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe data

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or transfer station
Don't put in blue bin
notes: Cables tangle in machinery
commonMistakes: Never put in curbside recycling

materials.name: Wax paper / parchment paper
instructions: Place in green compost bin
Seattle accepts wax and parchment paper in compost
notes: Composting handles the wax coating
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue recycling bin

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in garbage
notes: Mixed materials; not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Fast food wrapper
instructions: Food-soiled wrappers: green compost bin
Clean paper wrappers: blue recycling bin
notes: Seattle composts all food-soiled paper
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in blue recycling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to transfer station or tire retailer
notes: Most shops accept old tires with purchase
commonMistakes: Don't dump illegally

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to transfer station or Home Depot/Lowe's
notes: Contains mercury
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage

compost: ALL food waste; meat, dairy, bones, fish, fruit, vegetables (MANDATORY)
Food-soiled paper; pizza boxes, paper plates, napkins, paper towels
trash: Plastic bags and film (or store drop-off)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

tips: ALL food MUST go in the green compost bin; it is ILLEGAL to put food in garbage in Seattle
Food-soiled paper (pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels) goes in green compost, not blue recycling
Styrofoam is BANNED; take to transfer station
Glass IS accepted in curbside recycling in Seattle
Seattle fines up to $50 for food in garbage
